review.title: FrameNet CNL: a Knowledge Representation and Information Extraction Language
review.abstract: The paper presents a FrameNet-based information extraction and knowledge representation framework, called FrameNet-CNL. The framework is used on natural language documents and represents the extracted knowledge in a tailor-made Frame-ontology from which unambiguous FrameNet-CNL paraphrase text can be generated automatically in multiple languages. This approach brings together the fields of information extraction and CNL, because a source text can be considered belonging to FrameNet-CNL, if information extraction parser produces the correct knowledge representation as a result. We describe a state-of-the-art information extraction parser used by a national news agency and speculate that FrameNet-CNL eventually could shape the natural language subset used for writing the newswire articles.

metadata.title: FrameNet CNL: a Knowledge Representation and Information Extraction Language

sections.text: FrameNet-CNL, a framework for knowledge representation. This framework is used on documents in natural language and represents the extracted knowledge in a custom frame ontology from which unique FrameNet-CNL paraphrase text can be automatically generated in multiple languages. This approach combines the areas of information extraction and CNL, since a source code can be considered part of FrameNet-CNL if the information extraction parser produces the correct representation of knowledge as a result. We describe a state-of-the-art information extraction parser used by a national news agency and speculate that FrameNet-CNL could ultimately form the subset used to write the newswire articles in natural language. Keywords: knowledge representation, information extraction, FrameNet-CNL

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In Collaborative Reporting on the Characteristics and Perspectives of Science (CNL), the CNL was defined as a type of information system that focuses on the content of documents, with the ultimate goal of CNL research being human effort and reliability.

sections.heading: 2 FrameNet
sections.text: FrameNet 1 is a lexicographic database that describes word meanings based on the principles of framesemantics. [1] The central idea of framesemantics is that word meanings must be described in relation to semantic frames. Therefore, the frame and the lexical unit are the key components of FrameNet. A lexical unit is the combination of a problem with a meaning - each new meaning of a word represents a new lexical unit. In FrameNet, each lexical unit refers to a semantic framework it purports to evoke. FrameNet's framework descriptions are coarse-grained and generalize lexical variation. Although FrameNet addresses all parts of the speech as a frame evoking lexical units, its focus focuses on verbs for which the best coverage is provided. The semantic framework describes a particular situation and the participants in that situation, which are likely to be mentioned in the sentences in which the target lexical elements are presented as small (in English) frames.

sections.heading: 2.2 “Latvian” FrameNet Subset
sections.text: The Latvian FrameNet was created for a practical information extraction system developed for a national news agency to automatically extract biographical data on publicly visible persons and organizations mentioned in the Newswire articles. One design decision was to use a reduced number of frames - although our methodology applies to any number of frames, we have selected only 26 frames from the 1019 frames of English FrameNet version 1.5 (birth, people by age, death, personal relationship, naming, residence, education, people by vocation, people by origin, occupation, hiring, employment, membership, leadership change, giving, intentionally create, participation, income and losses, public procurement, possession, lending, testing, attack, profit, statement, product line) that were of interest to the national news agency; this use case also dictated the addition or removal of some frame elements (arguments) - the resulting frames are presented in the figure, statement, statement, product line) that is also applicable to the English FrameNet.

sections.heading: 4 Information Extraction with FN-CNL
sections.text: The increasing accuracy of frame semantic parsing (discussed in Section 2.1) allows the streamlining of information extraction task from natural language texts, such as newswire articles. Essentially, the goal of such information extraction is to populate the ontology shown in Fig.4 with instance data from the source code. To this end, frame semantic parser (produces instances for the blue boxes in Fig. 4) must be combined with Cross Document Coreference (CDC) techniques to automatically determine which mentions in the text refer to the same real entity (instances for the yellow boxes in Fig. 4). We have implemented such an integrated information extraction system and populated it with data from about 1 million newswire articles. From a practical standpoint, it turned out that the bottleneck of the approach is named entity detection and linking of accuracy - even at an estimated 80% accuracy CDC-like entries - they merge with different entries.

sections.heading: 5 FrameNet Controlled Natural Language (FN-CNL)
sections.text: FN-CNL was inspired by the PAO-CNL approach described in [6]. As illustrated in Fig. 1, FNCNL is a verbalization of the content of the knowledge base (in whole or in part) using a FrameNet verbalization framework, such as [11]. We implemented FN-CNL verbalization for 26 frames in the Latvian FrameNet and also tested that frame semantic parsing on this FN-CNL output achieves almost 100% accuracy (which can be further improved by manually editing human editable C6.0 frames). FN-CNL verbalization examples can potentially be used for learning unique FN-CNL examples by human writers. In general, FN-CNL is not limited to 26 frames of the Latvian FrameNet - FN-CNL, which are presented as the first multilinguistic FN manual.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We have illustrated the mutually enriching relationship between information extraction and CNL domains, and described a complete framework for extracting information from natural languages based on FN-CNL and AKR.
